Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2017 07:14PM - edited Jun 11, 2017 07:15PM by julie75 I am 60 years old, and I recently tested positive for the CHEK2 mutation (last week I received this info.) I have the IVS2+1G>A gene mutation. I had a BMX in 2010 and had SO HOPED to be past worrying about any type of cancer. My oncologist just gave me permission to see her once/year. Oh, well. Such things happen. Does anyone know how much the risk of ovarian cancer is increased with this mutation? I thought I read the possibility of low-grade ovarian cancer was increased, but not higher grades. Also, from what I read, my risk of colon cancer has increased, but I believe colon cancer develops more slowly. I'm not terribly worried about that portion of it. My colonoscopy 7 years ago came back clean. I'll be scheduling another colonoscopy within the next few weeks. Just as an FYI, my sister had breast cancer, and she had a lumpectomy several years ago. My brother had colon cancer roughly 20 years ago, and has been cancer-free since then. I'm considering a prophylactic removal of my ovaries. From what I've read, ovarian cancer is sneaky and, being the worrier that I am, removing them might be the way to go. Thoughts? Thanks for reading this--any advice is appreciated. Julie
Posts.Title: Anyone out there with the Chek2 gene mutation??? MNTaylor80 kber

Good luck to both of you (and everyone else above as well). Julie

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2010 09:36PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:12AM by julie75 Sue:  Yes, it's okay to cry and vent and worry about all of this!  You'll be fine.  Sounds like you've got a caring, compassionate radiology tech who will be working with you.  For each step in the process, the doctor told me exactly what he was going to do, and then did it. As I've told other ladies on this forum, there was a bit of compression on my breast, but nothing like a mammogram.  The needle does hurt a bit, but not too badly.  I was a bit sore for one day afterwords and had some slight bruising.  Take a Xanax, and you'll be fine.  Two hours seems like a long time for two biopsies; I'm thinking they just want to be sure they can take all the time they need to get accurate biopsies as possible.  Hopefully, it won't take two hours!!!  It was cool, being that high up; I sat up as they lowered the table. (Little kids would love that part!) On a humorous note, I had mine early in the morning without my usual cup of coffee, so I wasn't very alert.  The doctor asked me a question twice before I responded .   Sending strength and good thoughts your way. worriedwoman:  I'm sorry they want another biopsy.  Yes, this is one bumpy journey; I've had some unexpected events crop up as well.  We're here for you! Julie

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 10:34PM - edited Mar 5, 2011 10:35PM by julie75 Hi, Russian_Postman: I'm sorry you are having to go through all of this; as many other posters here say, "welcome to the club that nobody wants to join". Regarding taking all lymph nodes, I believe doctors here perform a "sentinel lymph node biopsy" here in the U.S. before deciding to remove any lymph nodes. Here is more information on the sentinel lymph node biopsy: http://www.uihealthcare.com/topics/medicaldepartments/cancercenter/sentinelnodebiopsy/index.html As to going back to work, I've heard of people taking only two weeks after a mastectomy, then going back to work. It just depends on how well you heal. Regarding immediate construction, this is a procedure whereby they can place tissue expanders under your chest muscles and fill them with saline. I had this procedure done when I had my bilateral mastectomy, which was on 09/17/10; in my case, the procedure is referred to as a "skin-sparing mastectomy". They were able to save my right nipple. When I woke up, I had breasts roughly the same size as I had before. I wanted to go up a cup size, so the tissue expanders were inflated over several two-week intervals. I just had my replacement surgery with silicone implants on 01/24/11. I did have several complications; the tissue expander on my left side was leaking, so they had to replace that. Also, I had some necrosis on my left side; that had to be removed. Due to these complications, I was off work for about 6 months, but many people go back to work between operations (it took me about 1 week to recover from each surgery). I'll be getting my left nipple reconstructed, along with some tatooing to reconstruct the left aureola. I'm not sure why your doctor is telling you "two years". That seems a bit long to me, unless you want to take time off between the different phases of reconstruction. I know women who have waited several months, to several years, before undergoing reconstruction. I understand completely your resignation and anger; I feel the same way at times. But, the scars will fade; mine are looking better every day. Again, this is just my experience . . . I think there are several other bc.org threads that have dealt with mastectomies scheduled in previous months. You may want to check those out. Best of luck to you, and everyone else undergoing this. Julie
Posts.Title: March 2011 Mastectomy elmcity69 Glo3mom

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2011 01:22PM julie75 wrote: Kezzie:  You will be okay . . . the waiting is the worst part.  *If* you can keep busy, that will help.  I worked right up until the day before I had my BMX; it kept me from thinking and worrying too much. Rnjules:  Glad to hear about the negative pathology report.  Yes, those drains really are a nuisance; I hope you get them out ASAP. As for the fills, those definitely can be uncomfortable.  You can work with your PS on this and decide how much you want the tissue expanders filled. brca1953:  I, too, am conscious about my scars.  I definitely get upset, looking at them, at times, but they WILL fade. Once the implants have been placed, ask your PS how soon you can start using silicone strips (or something else) to treat them.  (My PS told me to wait 3 months after my implants were placed before treating my scars.) For those who may have nausea issues from the anesthesia - there is an anti-nausea drug, called "Zophran", that can be added to the  anesthesia.  This drug helped me. carylc:  Hope you are doing okay.   RedSkyAtNight:  Thinking of you today.   Again, if any of you have questions, don't hesitate to PM me. Sending thoughts of strength. Julie

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2010 08:05AM - edited Dec 31, 2010 08:13AM by julie75 Thought I'd follow up and post my diary of my BMX as well - in part to keep this thread going. In September, 2008, my mammogram showed calcifications in my left breast.  Needless to say, this threw me and my husband into a major worry spin, which was made worse by having to wait one month before a sonoscan could be performed.  The sonoscan results at that time indicated that the calcifications were not malignent.  My 2009 mammogram didn't show any changes.   In August, 2010, I felt a hard spot in my left breast, and immediately contacted my General Practitioner (GP).  She ordered a sonoscan for me.  The radiologist looked the sonoscan over, and scheduled a stereotatic biopsy, which then indicated that I had DCIS Stage 0 in my left breast.   Since I didn't want to go through more worry, I decided to have a BMX, even though my right breast didn't have any indication of cancer.  On 09/17/10, I had this surgery, complete with reconstruction.  The good news was the tumor (7 cm x 4.5 cm x 2 cm) had not spread to the surrounding tissue.  Therefore, I am blessed with not having to do chemo, radiation or drugs like Tamoxifen. On 10/17, I had a second operation to excise necrosis on my left breast. Once that healed, I received fills every two weeks until 12/6, when my PS discovered that the TE under my left breast was leaking; I had that replaced then. On 12/27/10, I had a colonoscopy, which came back normal - more good news. Today is 12/30/10, and I am counting my blessings again.  I am enjoying breasts that are finally balanced with my hips (my breasts were always about 1.5 inches smaller than my hips) and have decided to treat myself to liposuction of my thights and butt as my way of enjoying life.   Strength to all of you going through this.  My faith in God has gotten me through this; my DH has been my backbone, as well as my family and friends.   As mjbmiller indicated, do as much research as possible.  I spent countless hours on the Internet, surfing for all information I could possibly get my hands on.  Talking to friends and family always helps - you'll need a support system.   And, allow yourself to cry and get those bad feelings out.  I was so drained after talking to doctors that I would take the rest of the day off of work.  Due to my complications, I won't be returning to work until the implants are placed.  Please take as much time as you need to heal - emotionally and physically. {{{HUGS}}} Julie

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 10:55PM - edited Mar 8, 2011 02:54AM by julie75 Just a few suggestions for dealing with those darn drains: 1.  My Plastic Surgeon (P.S.) suggested that I put Neosporin (or some other antibacterial salve) over the holes where they go in. 2.  I tied cloth belts around my waist and pinned the drains to them so they wouldn't get accidentally pulled, which can (obviously) cause pain. 3.  It's my understanding drains will come out when the fluid accumulation is less than 30 cc's/day (I had to empty mine twice/day). 4.  There are several websites that sell drain pouches:  http://www.vidacura.com/product/4048/354_Surgicalaftercare_Mastectomy; http://www.thepinkbra.com/trulife601.html. Just a few suggestions . . . Julie

Good luck, Flygirl239.  I second trail2's best wishes to everyone else who will be going through this in March. Julie

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 01:37AM - edited Jan 5, 2011 01:44AM by julie75 My best wishes for smooth sailing during surgery, and a speedy recovery to all. Had my BMX on 09/17/10. When going to the surgery, I was escorted into the hospital by a wonderful African-American nurse who said, "it will be a breeze".  Just hearing that made me feel a lot better.  And, really, it wasn't too bad.  Took Vicodin for about one week afterwords, then over-the-counter pain relievers.  Within two weeks, I was taking slow (2.5 mph) walks on the treadmill.  The drains were the worst part, but I kept them pinned to cloth belts around my waist.  If anyone has questions, feel free to PM me. Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 04:09AM julie75 wrote: Hello, twinkly and Everyone: Thanks for asking about me.  Today is 05/01/11, and I've had my final implant surgery on 01/24.  I will be posting the photos here, as soon as I have the nipple reconstruction some time in July. Right now, I'm feeling quite well.   I've lsot about 15 pounds from 01/24 to now (all intentionally) and am back to work.  Also, I'm taking a UCLA Extension computer course.  I have my 6-month oncology followup; no reason that shouldn't come back clear. Although I detest the scars at times, I know I have to be patient and wait for them to fade.  I don't have any keloids to speak of, and am just waiting to see how the final results turn out. I'm keeping this thread as one of my favorites, and will check back to see how everyone is doing. {{{HUGS}}} Julie
